svg.text: The complete description of the RL problem ‚Äî the "rules of the game"
V(s) = R(s,a) + Œ≥ Œ£ P(s'|s,a) ¬∑ V(s')
Value of state = immediate reward + discounted future value
üí° This recursive property enables all RL algorithms ‚Äî values depend on other values
Return (G) is what we're trying to predict (the "brute force" infinite sum)
Bellman Equation is HOW we calculate it efficiently (recursive: break into "now" + "future")
Instead of summing infinite rewards, just compute: V(s) = R + Œ≥¬∑V(next) ‚Äî same answer, way faster!
3. Two Approaches to Solving RL Problems
Model-Based (when you know the rules) vs Model-Free (when you learn by doing)
üé≤ You know P(s'|s,a) and R(s,a) ‚Äî the complete rules
üéÆ You DON'T know the rules ‚Äî learn from experience
üìä When tables are too big ‚Üí Use approximation
Instead of: Storing V(s) for every state in a table
Use: Parameterized function V(s; w) ‚âà V(s)
Examples: Linear functions, Neural networks (Deep RL)
"Draw a best-fit line instead of memorizing every point" | ‚úì Huge state spaces | ‚úì Generalizes | ~ Approximation error
‚ö†Ô∏è 6. The Deadly Triad: When RL Can Diverge
üí• All 3 together = High risk of divergence! (e.g., Q-learning + Neural Nets + Off-policy)
Solutions: Experience Replay, Target Networks, Importance Sampling, Better Algorithms (PPO, SAC)
